description.narrative: Strengthen institutional, scientific, technical, informational and human capacity which is a pre-requisite for effective climate change implementation in the country.
The overall aim of this project is to strengthen national capacity for climate change mitigation and adaptation in Zimbabwe.
independent political entity
Energy - power generation

1.National climate change strategy in place 2.Sector assessments study reports in place 3. Amount of global climate change financial resources mobilised 4. Functional designated national authority, Inter-Ministerial Committee on climate change and lower lever climate change structures in place 5. Updated National Energy policy and implementation plan with a strong focus on energy conservation and efficiency and renewables

comment.narrative: Low levels of CC awareness among decision makers and the public;no national climate change policy framework in place; insufficient demdemonstrable evidence on workable adaptation and mitigation measures ;lack of in-depth sectoral assessments to inform climate change policy formulation; weak coordination and implementation capacity of the Ministry of Environment for climate change programmes and resource mobilisation from global funding windows; uptake of energy efficient, clean & renewable energy technologies very low

description.narrative: Strengthening national capacities for public finance, aid and debt management to guarantee sucessful implementation of the Government national development strategy.
The Aid management Project will through a comprehensive approach, work towards strengthening institutions and mechanisms to support the countrys longer term development
independent political entity
policy, planning and administration

Number of Economic Publications Developed Financial reports produced timorously (within statutory deadlines). 100% system usage across all provinces % progress made in policy review Error free debt Statistics reports Budget figures allocated to MDG based sectors Number of parliamentarians trained on economic and human development literacy Number of CBO Strategic Plans and Budgets Plans are MDG based. Number of MDGs met at community level Number of publicity seminars on Post 2015 Development Agenda Number of people completed MDG VLC basic course & intermediate courses Number of district MDG Acceleration Plans Number of MDG-based plans and budgets Number of MSPs on MDGs convened Number of community driven initiatives on the implementation of MDG plans involving the private sector

comment.narrative: Zero 2012 MDG Progress Report 2007 NHDR 60 % 40 % Aid Coordination Policy (2009) Mechanisms 50% The 2014 National Budget 6 Little involvement and consultation of CBOs on national and international processes. Targets on several MDGs lagging behind 5 1800 7 Plans in place 3 3 MSPS on MDGs convened Zero initiatives 2013 project implementation reports

Publish Final Zimbabwe MDG Report Develop Post-2015 National Position Paper Participate in the Global SDG Consultation Forums Install Aid Management Information System Conduct a final evaluation of the debt management project Train 50 government accountants in mandatory courses Finalize District Development Acceleration Plans Actively engage community representatives and private sector in the implementation of acceleration plans Develop an Accelerated Action Plan on Food Security Undertake DMFAS Reporting and Analysis Training

Draft of Final Zimbabwe MDG Report in place Post-2015 National Position Paper produced Draft Accelerated Action Plan on Food Security developed Sustainable Development Goals Virtual Learning Centre launched ZimAsset Mid Term Review Supported Public Sensitized to the Post 2015 Development Agenda

description.narrative: Strengthening National Gender Machinery - Gender Equality and Women Empowerment

title.narrative: BACK TO OFFICE REPORT Holistic Management Victoria Falls 4-5 July 2013
BACK TO OFFICE REPORT GEPMI Review Workshop Nyanga 16-21 June 2014

description.narrative: Strengthening the National Gender Machinery in Zimbabwe
independent political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - social services (incl youth development and women+ children)

1. Draft National Gender Policy Implementation Strategy in place 2. Framework for GEPMI institutionalization at a public administration /academic 3. Gender Legal Framework in place 4. Extent to which the M&E capacities of the National Gender Machinery are strengthened 5. Framework for women's participation in place 6. Extent to which legislations are gender sensitive 7. Number of women benefiting from economic empowerment and support to livelihoods initiatives

comment.narrative: Draft National Gender Policy in Place but there is no implementation strategy 0 institutionalization of gender responsive budgeting and GEPMI Limited expertise in mainstreaming gender in economic policy planning

1. National Gender Policy launched 2. Draft Framework for institutionalization of GEPMI developed 3. Draft Gender Commission Institutional Framework developed 4. Draft Institutional Assessment Report produced 5. A draft framework for the participation of women in decision making developed 6. Draft lobbying and advocacy tools developed 7. Family Law Manual produced and published 8. One women's economic empowerment high impact project commissioned 9. Draft Framework for the establishment of a Women's Bank developed

1. New MoWAGCD Minister to present revised final National Gender Policy to Cabinet for approval. 2. Consultations between MoWAGCD and the Ministry of Higher and Tertiary Education are on-going. Planned activity with representatives from Academic Universities and Institutions to sensitize them on the GEPMI. 3. Procurement of 5 computers for the newly appointed Commissioners. 4. Consultant to carry the assessment of the Ministry of Women Affairs is on board and working on an inception report. 5 & 6. A workshop on economic and political empowerment for women was held in collaboration with the Parliament of Zimbabwe in June 2015. A second workshop on lobbying and advocacy for increased participation of women in politics and decision making is scheduled for 18-21 August with the Women's Parliamentary Caucus (including women directly representing political parties in Parliament). 7. A provincial validation workshop was conducted for provincial development officers, districts development officers, development officers and ward coordinators in Bulawayo in July 2015. 8. 39 women miners participated at the Mine Entra where they were exposed to mining technology, policies and regulations, mining financing amongst others. A Monitoring or field visit was carried out in Gwanda where the high impact project will be located, to assess the preparedness of the women miners association including environmental issues. One stampmill and two compressors have been procured. 9. A consultant was identified (KPMG International) and the MoWAGCD and MoFED are engaging the consultant to ascertain when the assigment can start (UNDP has released $60,000 to kickstart the process).

description.narrative: Capacity building for the Justice Law and Order sector to strengthen the human rights, democracy and enhance peoples participation.

title.narrative: BToR UPR Drafting of the NPA 1st workshop July 2012
BToR Training on UN HR Mechanisms Nov 2012
Capacity Building for Justice Law and Order
Enhancing Justice Delivery Annual Work Plan 2012

description.narrative: Enhancing Justice Delivery and Human Rights for All
independent political entity
Justice, Law and Order - policy, planning and administration

1.a Level of participation by key stakeholders in the coordination meetings 1.b Number of coordination/briefing meetings held per year 2.a Number of access to justice and human rights policies and laws reformed 2.b Number of legal drafters trained 2.c Number of Law Officers trained (including LDC) 3.a Capacity gap analysis completed 3.b Number of harmonized training workshops held for the JLOS 4.a Number of legal aid offices established 4.b Number of people receiving free legal assistance 4.c Number of primary court officials trained 5.a Number of human rights instruments ratified 5.b Number of human rights instruments domesticated 6.a Number of state party reports submitted to treaty bodies 6.b Number of national follow up / implementation plans in place 7.Number of training held on HRBA

comment.narrative: 1. Limited coordination among all stakeholders in the JLOS 2. Laws and policies not in line with international obligations 3. Weak capacity in the JLOS 4. Fragmented information on accessing legal aid. Limited scope and coverage of legal aid assistance 5. Key human rights treaties not yet ratified and domesticated (CAT, CRPD, Optional Protocols on UN key treaties, AU treaties) Limited follow up of recommendations made from monitoring bodies (UPR). 6. Overdue state party reports to treaty bodies 7. Training of JLOS Members on HRBA but limited knowledge in the JLOS on the application of HRBA still exists

Support the JLOS coordination mechanism Finalise the JLOS communication strategy Support alignment of laws to the new constitution Conduct provincial UPR consultative meetings for Second Cycle Report Develop and support Cabinet approval of state party reports for Treaty Bodies Conduct comprehensive baseline survey on citizens experience in accessing justice

In supporting JLOS coordination, the Technical Committee constituted by 35 members (23 female and 12 male) met from the 17th to the 20th of March 2015 and review progress made during the previous year, review, refine and update the Strategic and Resource Mobilisation Plan for the JLOS, finalise the communication strategy, formulate policy recommendations for policy makers and reflect on linkages between the JLOS and the Organ of National Healing, Reconciliation and Integration. The State Party Reports on the African Charter on Human and Peoples Rights and its Protocol on Womens Rights and the Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights were adopted in March 2015 at workshops attended by (25participants, 11 males and 14 female and 24 participants; 15 females and 9 males) respectively and now await Cabinet. Provincial UPR consultative were as a process of engaging stakeholders and gathering information for the development of Zimbabwes 2nd cycle UPR report. The consultations also had a training component on the UPR process to impart knowledge on the UPR process so that inputs in the consultations would be made from an informed basis.

description.narrative: Strengthening the role of Civil Society Organizations (CSOs) in Human Rights reporting, monitoring and advocacy.

title.narrative: 00083255 BToR Validation of the Advocacy Strategy Sept 2013
Civil Society Human Rights Reporting Prodoc

description.narrative: This project recognizes that CSOs are critical to the building and strengthening of the human rights architecture in Zimbabwe; deepening democracy and enhancing citizen participation in governance affairs.
independent political entity
Other General Services - support to civil society

1.a Number of training carried out 1.b Capacity gap analysis completed 1.c NGO database created 1.d Annual Human Rights annual report produced 2. a Number of stakeholder consultations conducted (on legal and policy reform in operational and regulatory environment of CSOs) 2.b Number of CSO governing policies and laws reformed 3.a Number of Shadown reports produced and submitted to treaty monitoring bodies 3.b Number of training workshops conducted by CSOs on the human rights situation in Zimbabwe 4.a Number of advocacy tools produced on ratification and domestication 4.b UPR Follow up plan established 5. Baseline study completed (on transparency and accountability in the management of public resources) 6.a Partnerships established between CSOs and relevant stakeholders 6.b National Human Rights Platform established and functional 7. Number of trainings, workshops and community meetings conducted

comment.narrative: 1. Limited capacities within CSO to carry out effective project management 2. Repressive legislation governing the operating environment of CSOs 3. There is no collective contemporary information on the human rights situation in Zimbabwe 4. Poor State record of ratification and domestication of regional and international human rights instruments 5.Lack of a comprehensive CSO coordination mechanism to monitor the management of public resources 6.Lack of a comprehensive legal and policy framework promoting the efficient use of public resources 7.Limited citizen awareness and limited mechanisms for citizen involvement in democratic processes

1. Two status reports on CSOs and Human Rights reporting developed by December 2015. 2. Code of conduct on NGO self regulation in place by September 2015 3. At least two Shadow reports developed (including on the UNCRPD, on IESCR) 4. 2015 Annual Human Rights Report developed by December 2015 5. Baseline assessment on the free movement of people in SADC developed by June 2015 6. Observer status at the African Commission established by December 2015 7. National Human Rights Platform established by May 2015 8. Joint commemoration on the International Human Rights Day between State and Non State actors held by December 2015 9. Radio talk shows and road shows on human rights related issues held by December 2015

description.narrative: The Programme aims to build capacities in the local government sector focussing on developing an internally coherent and consistent constitutional/legislative framework and setting up sound administrative, management and accountability systems.

title.narrative: Capacity Building for the Local GovSector and Service Dlivery Programme Document pdf

description.narrative: This Programme recognizes the critical role that local government plays both in terms of deepening democracy and enhancing people participation. It aims to build capacities in the local government sector for more efficient service delivery to the people.
independent political entity
Accountability - local government finance

1. Draft Bills of the four principle Acts [Provincial Councils, Metropolitan Council and Traditional Leaders Harmonised Local Government Bills] in place 2. Functional systems in place for Local Government sector to implement IRBM 3. Local Development fund in place 4. 40 IRBM ToT, facilitators and resource persons trained 5. Strategy Paper on citizen participation in place

comment.narrative: 1. The 4 Principal Acts, Policy frameworks governing the Local Government sector are fragmented, outdated and not aligned to the Constitution. 2. Limited knowledge, capacities and institutional set ups in the Local Government sector to implement IRBM. 3. Absence of a local development fund. Unpredictable and unsustainable National fiscal transfer system presently in place. Inconsistencies in mobilization, transfer and use local generate revenue by local authorities. 4. No coordinated Human Skills Development plan and System for the Local Government Sector 5.There is inadequate civic participation in local governance affairs in the Local Government Sector.

1. Draft Local Government Policy and Legal Framework aligned to the Constitution 2. ICT audit for the Ministry of Local Government, Public Works and National Housing at Provincial and district level conducted 3. Draft national Fiscal Transfer Framework in place 4. Ministry of Local Government, Public Works and National Housing capacitated on functional duties 5. Standardized Civic Engagement Frameworks and Mechanisms in place in the Local Government Sector

1. The Local Authorities Bill is now at the Act drafting stage. 2. A draft ICT Strategy has been developed 3. Inter-governmental fiscal transfer framework has been developed and is going to be reviewed at national stakeholder consultations. The Local Authorities Appropriation Bill will be developed after the consultations.

title.narrative: Support to the Zimbabwe Human Rights Commission

description.narrative: Support for the strengthening of the promotion and protection of Human rights and Rule of Law through enhanced capacity of institutions in the Ministry of Justice and Legal Affairs

title.narrative: Back to Office Learning Visit Report Uganda FINAL REPORT
Support to Zimbabwe Human Rights Commission Project Document
Support for the strengthening of the promotion and protection of Human Rights and Rule of Law through enhanced capacity of institutions in the Ministry of Justice and Legal Affairs
Evaluation of Support to Strengthening the Zimbabwe Human Rights Commission

description.narrative: Capacity strengthening for the Zimbabwe Human Rights Commission
independent political entity
Human rights affairs

Number of monthly meetings held Report of ZHRC staff recruitment At least 3 Internal Control Manuals developed and in place Number of mission reports Number of brochures designed, printed, translated and disseminated Number of press statements commemorating human rights days ZHRC Annual report produced Number monitoring visits conducted Draft Baseline survey

comment.narrative: Limited internal coordination within the ZHRC Limited number of Secretariat positions filled Zero internal control frameworks Inadequate exposure, practice and knowledge sharing on human rights promotion and protection Limited information and knowledge management system (no website, documentation centre) Limited collaboration on national human rights issues; Limited knowledge on the role of ZHRC among stakeholders No framework for planning human rights interventions

1.a Induction workshop and teambuilding training conducted by June 2015 1.b Finance and Administrative Manual developed and adopted by 30 April 2015 2.a At least 4 Capacity building training workshops conducted for the ZHRC by December 2015 2.b At least 4 Monitoring and inspection report submitted to Parliament by October 2015 3. 2013 Annual report produced and disseminated by September 2015 4.a One civic education outreach conducted 4.b Quarterly investigative / monitoring visits conducted 5.a Baseline survey incorporating gender dimensions by June 2015 5.b Short Term ZHRC Strategic Plan by June 2015

1.b Two draft Internal control Frameworks (Human Resources Manual and a Finance and Administrative Manual) are undergoing validation processes by the ZHRC 2.b Two prison monitoring visits have been concluded in two provinces (Masvingo and Matebeleland) with reports and recommendations being prepared for Parliament. 5.a Final Baseline survey on the Human Rights Situation in the country completed and submitted 5.b On-going validation workshop for the Commission's Strategic Plan

title.narrative: Support to Peace Building Livelihoods Disaster Risk Mngt

description.narrative: Support to Peace Building, Disaster Risk Management and Increased Access to Sustainable Livelihoods for Resilience Building and Social Cohesion.
Capacities for Dialogue
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1. Number of citizen platforms of engagement and dialogue on the link between Peace, Reconciliation and Development with Government and the NPRC in place and operating. 2. Number of the youth (female and male) attending the dialogue platforms 3. Number of inclusive multi-stakeholder dialogue roundtable carried out on the NPRC (its function and mandate) and related issues; 4. A collaborative mechanism for early detection of potential conflict in place

comment.narrative: 1. Platforms for dialogue exist, but they need to be strengthened for national and structured engagement on peace, reconciliation and long-term development 2. Limited consensus on factors undermining processes aimed at promoting healing and reconciliation

1. At least 3 strategic institutions equipped with dialogue and mediation skills 2. At least 10 dialogue round tables around peace and reconciliation convened 3. At least 2 Knowledge products on UNDP supported social cohesion efforts 4. At least 5 Sector Specific Strategy papers on their role in promoting peace and reconciliation published 5. At least one Creative sectors exhibition convened

1. 3 Institutions (CF, CCSF and ECLF) were equipped with dialogue and mediation skills 2. A total of 12 (7 national dialogue sessions with policy makers, 5 provincial) peacebuilding and reconciliation dialogue sessions including one brownbag seminar on the role of women in peacebuilding were convened 3. A documentary report and video on creative arts products was developed for the Chilelema (in Binga District) basketry group 4. A strategy paper on the role of the arts and culture in peace building and social cohesion was developed; 5. Creative basketry products were developed by a group of women from Chilelema in Binga District. The products were exhibited in September 2015 at the National Arts Gallery in Harare

description.narrative: Community Capacities For Peace
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

comment.narrative: 1. At least 30 LPCs are actively spearheading community development programmes (with at least 30% targeting women-specific initiatives) 2. At least 72 trained community peace facilitators are actively involved in local level peacebuilding efforts (at least 30 % being women) 3. Guidance note on how to support the establishment of LPCs in place by December 2015 4. At least 40 Community Peace Outreach and Sensitization Workshops held (with 50% women participation).

1. A total of 8 Local Peace Committees in Nkayi, Mhondoro, Mudzi and Chivi Districts were capacitated to integrate livelihoods into peace building interventions 2. 78 trained peace facilitators (51 males and 27 females) are actively involved in local level peacebuilding efforts supporting capacity building of Local Peace Committees 3. A guidance note on how to support the establishment of LPCs was finalised 4. 110 Community based Peace Outreach and sensitization workshops were conducted and 3503 participants (1654 Females and 1849 Males) attended.

title.narrative: Multi Donor Support Prog for P

description.narrative: Multi Donor Support Prog for P

1.a Pieces of Legislation passed / aligned to the Constitution 1.b Baseline report studies completed by Q4 1.c Number of Portfolio and Thematic Committee trained in legislative and policy analysis 2.a Number of reports received and reviewed within statutory time frames 2.b Number of Portfolio and Thematic Committee public hearing in at least five provinces annually 2.c Number of consultative meetings on the roles and functions of ministries 2.d Number of Portfolio and Thematic Committees trained in legislative oversight and representative functions 2.d Code of Conduct and Ethics in place 2.e Number of audit carried out using the Customized and Regularity Manual 2.f Revised Strategic Plan Document (2014-2018) 3.a Number of public hearings in legislative, oversight and representation functions of Parliament 3.b Number of women-specific issues from public hearings discussed in the National Assembly and the Senate 4.a Coordination framework in place 4.b Comprehensive skills audit report of both Members of Parliament and Staff 4.c Gender sensitive Human Resources Development Strategy 4.d Report of customer satisfaction surveys for MPs, Staff and external stakeholders 5.a Number of Committees mainstreaming gender 5.b Gender Policy in place 5.c Number of members effectively contributing to legislative debate

comment.narrative: 1. Knowledge and skills deficits in legislative and policy analysis (Baseline Survey and 60% of new members) 2. a Non adherence to constitutional requirements on submission of reports, Ministries, Parastatals and State Entreprises reports on the use and management of public resources; 2.b Baseline survey on Committees Specific Issues (2011) 2.c 2010 Draft Code of Conduct and Ethics 2.d 2012 Auditor General Consolidated Report 3. 2011 Baseline survey on Committee Specific issues 4.a 2010-2011 PSP Evaluation Report (2012) 4.b Draft ICT Policy 2011 4.c 2011 Baselines of both Members of Parliament 5.a Gender training manual, Administration of Parliament draft Gender Policy 5.b No Strategic Plan, inadequate skill of members to effectively debate

description.narrative: Increased capacities of communities to protect development gains and achieve improved well-being outcomes in the face of shocks and stresses enabling them to contribute to the economic growth of Zimbabwe

Increased capacities of communities to protect development gains and achieve improved well-being outcomes in the face of shocks and stresses enabling them to contribute to the economic growth of Zimbabwe

OUTPUT 1: Application of evidence in policy making for resilience increased.
# of relevant risk and vulnerability information disseminated to stakeholders. # capacity assessments of government. # if capacity building opportunities with partners identified.
OUTPUT 2: Absorptive, Adaptive and Transformative capacities of at-risk communities increased and improved via ZRBF investments.
% Households (HH) with improved coping strategies. % of communities utilizing DRM plans in response. % of communities implementing appropriate natural resource management plans. % of communities implementing informal safety nets. % of communities with appropriate collective action responses to shocks and stresses. % of HHs with access to improved safe drinking water and safe sanitation facilities. % of communities with effective management of public goods. Markets functioning in the face of stresses.
OUTPUT 3: Timely and cost effective response to emergencies rolled out via existing safety net and other relevant programmes.
#early warning mechanisms supported # response mechanisms identified
-

comment.narrative:
OUTPUT 1: Application of evidence in policy making for resilience increased.
- No evidence base for policy making for resilience.
OUTPUT 2: Absorptive, Adaptive and Transformative capacities of at-risk communities increased and improved via ZRBF investments.
- Unknown (baseline will be done as part of the project)
OUTPUT 3: Timely and cost effective response to emergencies rolled out via existing safety net and other relevant programmes.
-

OUTPUT 1: Application of evidence in policy making for resilience increased.
-National risk and hazard profile for resilience building prepared and endorsed
-M&E system developed
-Consensus around Theory of Change built
OUTPUT 2: Absorptive, Adaptive and Transformative capacities of at-risk communities increased and improved via ZRBF investments.
- ZRBF management unit fully functioning - Funding modalities designed - ToRs for Steering Committee Developed - Office spaces identified and organized - First RfP developed
OUTPUT 3: Timely and cost effective response to emergencies rolled out via existing safety net and other relevant programmes.
- Mechanisms developed to identify triggers and improve preparedness -Response mechanisms identified

OUTPUT 1: Application of evidence in policy making for resilience increased.
-A National multi hazard index was developed to the lowest administrative level (ward level) accompanied by hazard specific and combined maps. The methodology and products were endorsed by a multi stakeholder workshop in September 2015. A publication is currently under development.
-The development of the M&E system was postponed and is expected to be finalized by mid 2016
- Consensus has been build between Government, UN, Civil Society and Academia around a Strategic Framework for Resilience in Zimbabwe. Consultations to build consensus around the Theory of Change for ZRBF have been on-going since August 2015 and reached between UN and Government. The multi stakeholder consultation will be finalized in January 2016
OUTPUT 2: Absorptive, Adaptive and Transformative capacities of at-risk communities increased and improved via ZRBF investments.
- The ZRBF management unit has undertaken recruitment of 4 out of 10 project staff members and is partially functioning. Office spaces have been identified and organized. Procurement processes are on-going for refurbishment and vehicles.
Funding modalities under ZRBF has been proposed to an accepted by funding donors and a procurement strategy developed. The ToRs for the project steering committee have been developed. A EoI was conducted as part of the funding modality and a RfP is expected to be released end of January 2016
OUTPUT 3: Timely and cost effective response to emergencies rolled out via existing safety net and other relevant programmes.
The development of the crisis modifier has been postponed to first quarter of 2016
